review.title: Focused Meeting Summarization via Unsupervised Relation Extraction
review.abstract: We present a novel unsupervised framework for focused meeting summarization that views the problem as an instance of relation extraction. We adapt an existing in-domain relation learner (Chen et al., 2011) by exploiting a set of task-specific constraints and features. We evaluate the approach on a decision summarization task and show that it outperforms unsupervised utterance-level extractive summarization baselines as well as an existing generic relation-extraction-based summarization method. Moreover, our approach produces summaries competitive with those generated by supervised methods in terms of the standard ROUGE score.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: For better or worse decision making, meetings play an important role in most of our daily lives - they let us share information and collaborate with others to solve a problem, generate ideas and weigh options. Unsurprisingly, there is a growing interest in developing automatic methods for summarizing meetings (e.g. Zechner (2002), Maskey and Hirschberg (2005), Lin and Chen (2010), Murray et al.). This paper addresses the task of focused conference summaries, i.e. it generates summaries of a particular aspect of a meeting rather than the meeting as a whole (Carenini et al).

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: Most research on spoken dialogues summary tries to generate summaries for full dialogues (Carenini et al., 2011), but has only recently tackled the task of focused summary and decision summary, in particular. Ferna ́ ndez et al. (2008) and Bui et al. (2009) employ supervised learning methods to evaluate phrases or words for inclusion in decision summary. In comparison, Ferna ́ ndez et al. sections.heading: 4 Model
sections.text: In this section we describe the Chen et al. (2011) probabilistic relationship learning model used for both Decision Cue and Decision Content Relationship Extraction. The parameter estimation and constraint encoding through posterior inference are presented in Section 5. The relationship learning model takes as input clusters of DRDAs, sorted by time of expression and concatenated in a decision document. We assume that one decision is made per document. The aim of the model is to explain how the decision documents are generated from the latent relation variables. The downstream regulation technique (Section 5) tends to draw conclusions about the declarative limitations of relation instances. Instead of strictly extracting relation instances, features and constraints are designed in such a way that the model detects various relationship types and ensures that the identified relation instances are coherent and significant.

sections.heading: 9 Conclusions
sections.text: We present a novel framework for focused meeting summaries based on unattended relation extraction. It turns out that our approach performs better in terms of standard ROUGE score versus unattended exposure level extractive summarization baselines and an existing generic relation extraction-based summarization method. Overall, we find that relationship-based methods for focused summaries have potential as a technique to support abstract decision summarization generation.
